posts.name: Sylvain D.
posts.cooked:
Last week we discovered that one of our Max Swerve modules had several issues.

First (and reason we took it appart) the turning encoder was broken: casing chipped and the switch was broken.

The inside of the module was full of aluminum dust. See picture below. IMG_6744 1920×2560 442 KB

IMG_6744 1920×2560 442 KB

IMG_6744 1920×2560 442 KB

Finally after investigation, we found the driving gear (14T) was completely worn. IMG_6743 1920×1440 156 KB

IMG_6743 1920×1440 156 KB

IMG_6743 1920×1440 156 KB

Has anybody experienced this before? Any idea where to look at for the source of this issue?

posts.name: Miles Irwin
posts.cooked: is the extrusion you’re using for the frame solid without precut holes because if it is then whenever you drill holes into it all the shavings will slide into your swerve modules. our team prevented this by using 2x1 with precut holes so you don’t have to drill as much and if there are metal shavings inside the extrusion then it will just fall out. something we also do after drilling anything above them is using this electric air blower tool and we just blow out the swerve modules after stuff could fall in.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: How well, and how often did you grease that module?  Reminds me of ungreased modules.

posts.name: Sylvain D.
posts.cooked: These  are new modules mounted and greased in October. We did practice and one competition. I will totally ask the students to check this out!

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Greased once, in October?

Yeah, that would do it.  What kind of grease was used?  Red tacky?

posts.name: Sylvain D.
posts.cooked:
roomba1813:

swerve modules. our team prevented this by using 2x1 with precut holes so you don’t have to drill

We are using MaxTubes pre-drilled and have covers on the modules.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: Wow, we’ve never seen this level of wear. The gears are all steel so they should be lasting quite a while.
